The was the Eight of Guard and Custody (Otto di guardia e balia), a body elected every four months, which acted as a tribunal for criminal and political cases. It could inflict capital punishment by a vote of six out of its eight members. As the vote was taken by beans being placed in a bag the Court became known as the Sei Fave or Six Beans.

characters.name: Dovizi, Ser Piero, also called Ser Piero da Bibbiena (Hist.)
characters.desc: "The weasel that Piero de' Medici keeps at his beck to slip through small holes for him." Brother of Bernardo Dovizi. Piero da Bibbiena, secretary to Piero de' Medici, who had previously held the same office under Piero's father, Lorenzo de' Medici. He was hated by the people and was forced to flee from Florence at the same time as Piero de' Medici.

characters.name: Dovizi, Bernardo, of Bibbiena (Hist.)
characters.desc: An acquaintance of Tito Melema. Bernarda Dovizi da Bibbiena, later Cardinal da Bibiena (1470-1520), an Italian eccleseastic and poet, created Cardinal 1513, author of La Calandria.

characters.name: Dominicans, or, Frati Predicatori (Hist.)
characters.desc: The monastic order to which Savonarola belongs. Savonarola is a Dominican, as also Fra Domenico who takes up the Fraciscan challenge to the Trial by Fire, and Fra Salvestro who is Romola's confessor. It was the Dominicans that Romola's brother Bernardino de' Bardi joined when he left home, he goes to their monastery at Fiesole when he is ill, and dies at the Dominican convent of San Marco in Florence, of which Savonarola is Prior. The Dominicans, or Order of Preachers (Ordo Predicatorum) founded by St. Dominic in 1215.

characters.name: Domenico, Fra (Hist.)
characters.desc: A Dominican brother of San Marco, Savonarola's lieutenant. When the Franciscan Fra Francesco challenges Savonarola to the Trial by Fire, Fra Domenico enthusiastically takes up the challenge. He is the Dominican representative in the Trial by Fire and later is one of the Dominicans arrested with Savonarola and executed with him. Fra Domenico Bonvicini da Pescia, the loyal friend and coadjutor of Savonarola, who was exectured with Savonarola.

characters.name: Cronaca (Hist.)
characters.desc: An architect, who is a devoted adherent of Savonarola; one of the patrons of Nello the barber. Simone Pollajuola, called Il Cronaca (1457-1508), a celebrated Florentine architect.

characters.name: Crisolora (The Younger) (Hist.)
characters.desc: A Greek scholar, under whom Bardo de' Bardi had once studied. This was John Crisolora (died about 1427), who accompanied his uncle to Italy and became a professor of Greek. His uncle Manuel Crisolora (ca. 1350-1415), who came from Constantinople, and taught Greek in Florence and other Italian cities, is also mentioned by Bardo in Chapter vi of Romola.

characters.name: Crinito, Pietro (Hist.)
characters.desc: A "scholar of the more polished sort". Pietro Riccio, called Crinito or Crinitus (1465-1505), a Florentine poet and biographer.

characters.name: Credi, Lorenzo di (Hist.)
characters.desc: Painter, who assisted at the Bonfire of Vanities. Lorenzo di Credi (1459-1537), Florentine painter, and lifelong friend of Leonardo da Vinci, who came under the influence of Savonarola.

characters.name: Cosimo, Piero di (Hist.)
characters.desc: An eccentric painter, one of the patrons of Nello's shop, who does not share Nello's admiration for Tito Melema. From the beginning he dislikes Tito Melema, suspecting him of concealing a cowardly and treacherous nature behind his bright face. He paints a picture of Bardo and Romola as "Oedipus and Antigone", and at Tito's request he paints the triptych decorated with the story of Bacchus and Ariadne, in which Tito has Romola lock up her brother's crucifix. For himself he paints a picture of Tito struck by fear, completing it by adding the picture of Baldassarre Calvo after he has seen the latter clutch Tito on the steps of the Duomo. Piero di Lorenzo, called Cosimo from his master, Cosimo Rosselli (1441-1521); a Florentine painter of an eccentric and cynical nature, who painted many fanciful paintings, For the account of him which George Eliot evidently used see Vasari, Lives. Vasari gives his date of birth as 1441, but some other authorities give 1462.

characters.name: Corsini, Luca (Hist.)
characters.desc: Doctor of Law, an adherent of Savonarola, who was to have delivered an oration in Latin at the entrance of Charles VIII into Florence. Luca Corsini, a wealthy and influential member of a powerful family. In 1494 he refused to admit Piero de' Medici to the palace.

characters.name: Compagnacci, or Evil Companions (Hist.)
characters.desc: "Compagnacci, or Evil Companions… all the dissolute young men belonging to the old aristocratic party, enemies of the Mediceans, enemies of the popular government, but still more bitter enemies of Savonarola. Dolfo Spini, heir of the great house with the loggia, over the bridge of the Santa Trinta, had organized these young men into an armed band, as  sworn champions of extravagant suppers and all the pleasant sins of the flesh, against reforming pietists."

characters.name: Comines, Philippe de (Hist.)
characters.desc: A French statesman in the train of Charles VIII. Philippe de Comines, Sieur d'Argenton (1445-1509).

characters.name: Cioni, Ser (Hist.)
characters.desc: A thin notary, member of Savonarola's party. Filippo Cioni, a notary who in 1496 wrote an Epistle in defence of Savonarola.

characters.name: Charles VIII (Hist.)
characters.desc: The French king, who enters Florence in 1494. If the young monarch under the canopy, seated on his charger with his lance upon his thight, had looked more like a Charlemagne and less like a hastily modelled grotesque, the imagination of his admirers would have been much assisted. It might have been wished that the scourge of Italian wickedness and 'Champion of the honour of women' had had a less miserable leg, and only the normal sum of toes; that his mouth had been of a less reptilian width of slit, his nose and head of a less exorbitant outline." Charle VIII (1470-98), king of France 1483-98. In 1494 Lodovico Il Moro asked Charles for help against Naples, and Charles went to Italy and conquered Naples. George Eliot's account of the events of his entry into Florence follows history closely.

characters.name: Cennini, Pietro (Hist.)
characters.desc: Goldsmith and printer, the younger brother of Domenico; an "erudite corrector of proof-sheets", who employs Tito Melema to help in editing his classical texts. Pietro Cennini, writer, humanist, and printer, born 1445, who in 1470-71 worked as "emendator" on his father's edition of the Commentary on Virgil. George Eliot makes him the younger of the two brothers, but he was seven years older than Domenico.

characters.name: Cennini, Domenico (Hist.)
characters.desc: Son of Bernardo Cennini, the first printer of Florence; a goldsmith and printer with whom Tito Melema banks the money which he obtains from the sale of his rings. Domenico Cennini, goldsmith, born 1452, who in 1470-71 co-operated with his father, Bernar doCennini, in the printing of the Commentary on Virgil. George Eliot describes him as the eleder brother, but he was seven years younger than Pietro.

characters.name: Cei, Francesco (Hist.)
characters.desc: Popular poet; a frequenter of Nello's barber shop. He is an opponent of Savonarola. Francesco Cei was a Florentine poet of the second half of the fifteenth century, of a considerable reputation among his contemporaries. His only published work was a collection entitled: Sonecti, capitoli, canzoni, sextine stanze e strambatti, composti in laude di Clitia. Florence, 1503. This was reprinted several times under different titles.

characters.name: Ceccone, Ser, or Ser Francesco di Ser Barone (Hist.)
characters.desc: A "sharp-nosed notary of evil repute". While apparently a member of Savonarola's party he is secretly an agent of the Mediceans. When the Mediceans are arrested he tries to buy his own safety by betraying them, and hates Tito Melema as a more successful traitor than himself. Later he attaches himself to the Arrabbiati and Dolfo Spini, becomes a bitter enemy of Savonarola, and, at Savonarola's trial and torture, tampers with and perverts the evidence and confession. Ser Ceccone, or Ser Ceccone di Ser Barone, the infamous notary who falsified Savonarola's depositions.

characters.name: Cecca (Hist.)
characters.desc: Engineer, who had provided the huge drapery in the Piazza del Duomo for the Midsummer Day celebration. Francesco d'Angelo, called La Cecca (1447-1488), a famous Florentine engineer who devised ingenious machinery and elaborate decorations for the Midsummer Day and other great festivals and processions. For the description of these, from with George Eliot took her account, see Vasari, Lives.

characters.name: Carmelites (Hist.)
characters.desc: Monks who take part in the procession of L'Impruneta in Florence. One of the four great orders of the mendicants; founded 1156 by the Crusader Berthold, at Mr. Carmel, in Palestine.

characters.name: Capponi, Piero (Hist.)
characters.desc: One of the four syndics charged with effecting the treaty between Charles VIII and the people of Florence, who at the critical moment spoke out and opposed the king. Piero di Gino di Neri Capponi (1446-1496), a member of an illustrious family and gonfaloniere of Florence, who was especially celebrated for the courageous stand he took in the negotiations with Charles VIII.

characters.name: Caparra, Niccolo (Hist.)
characters.desc: Armourer; a famous worker in iron. "He was one of those figures for whom all the world instinctively makes way, as it would for a battering ram. He was not much above the middle height, but the impression of enormous force which was conveyed by his capacious chest, and brawny arms bared to the shoulder, was deepened by the keen sense and quiet resolution expressed in his glance and in every furrow of his cheek and brow. He had often been an unconscious model to Domenico Ghirlandajo, when that great painter was making the walls of the churces reflect the life of Florence." Tito Melema buys from him the coat of mail which he wears after the return of Baldassarre Calvo, and Baldassarre buys there the hunting knife with which he hopes to kill Tito. Niccolo Grosso, called Caparra from his habit of insisting on earnest money in any bargain.

characters.name: Cambini, Andrea (Hist.)
characters.desc: "A well-known satellite of Francesco Valori." Andrea Cambini, historian and translator, who lived during the second half of the fifteenth century. He was a zealous follower of Savonarola.

characters.name: Calimara, Corporation of (Hist.)
characters.desc: Dealers in foreign cloths to which a Florentine finish had been given; one of the corporations included in the San Giovanni procession. The Calimala, or dealers in foregin cloth, one of the seven Greater Arts (or Guilds) of Florence.

characters.name: Calderino (Hist.)
characters.desc: "Men like Calderino who, as Poliziano has well shown, have recourse to impudent falsities of citation to serve the ends of their vanity and secure a triumpth to their own mistakes." Domizio Calderino (1446-1478), famous philologist, philosopher, and mathematician.

characters.name: Calcondila, Demetrio (Hist.)
characters.desc: A Greek scholar to whose professorship of Greek in Florence Tito Melema succeeds. Demetrius Chalcondylae or Demetrio Calcondila, a Greek, who was brought to Florence by Lorenze de' Medici, was for more than twenty years professor of Greek in that city. He left Florence for Milan in 1492; died c. 1510 or 1513.

characters.name: Burchiello (Hist.)
characters.desc: A barber, Nello's great predecessor, often mentioned by him, whose shop was on the Calimara. "Now a barber can be dispassionate; the only thing he necessarily stands by is the razor, always providing he is not an author. That was the flaw in my great predecessor Burchiello: he was a poet, and had consequently a prejudice about his own poetry." Domenico di Giovanni, called Il Burchiello, poet and barber in Florence about 1404 and died at Rome 1448. His sonnets (first edition Bologna, 1474) were very popular, and were frequently reprinted.

characters.name: Buondelmonti (Hist.)
characters.desc: "High house of Buondelmonti, patrons of the church," guardians of the image of the Madonna dell' Impruneta. The Church of the Impruneta was founded by the Buondelmonti family.

characters.name: Bonsi, Domenico (Hist.)
characters.desc: A learned doctor of law; one of the four syndics or commissioners charged with the effecting of the treaty between Charles VIII of France and the people of Florence. Domenico Bonsi (1430-1501) was a Florentine diplomat of distinction and a partisan of Savonarola.

characters.name: Bonfire of Vanities (Hist.)
characters.desc: "On this day of the festival, at evening, the pile of vanities was to be set ablaze to the sound of trumpets, and the ugly old Carnival was to tumble into the flame amid the songs of reforming triumph." The first Bonfire of Vanities took place the 7th of February, 1497. A second one took place on the 27th of February, 1498.

characters.name: Bishop (Hist.)
characters.desc: The church dignitary who performs the ceremony of degradation on Savonarola, just before his execution. Benedetto Cristoforo de' Pagagnotti, Bishop of Vaison and Vicar - General of Florence.

characters.name: Benevieni, Girolamo (Hist.)
characters.desc: A mystic poet, an adherent of Savonarola. Girolamo Benevieni (1453-1542) was a religious and lyrical poet, whose poems voiced the ideas and aspirations of Savonarola.

characters.name: Benevieni, Antonio (Hist.)
characters.desc: "The greatest master of the chirurgio art," one of Nello's patrons. An Italian physician and professor of medicine, who was born at Florence, and died there 1502.

characters.name: Benedictines (Hist.)
characters.desc: Monastic order. The term Benedictines, or Black Monks, is the general name given to the monks living under the rule of St. Benedict, who himself founded the first Benedictine monastery.

characters.name: Beaucaire, Seneschal de (Hist.)
characters.desc: Great favourite of the French king, for whom he purchases Bardo de' Bardi's art treasures. Etienne de Vers, originally a lackey and later Seneschal Beaucaire.

characters.name: Bardi (Hist.)
characters.desc: The famous Florentine family to which Romola de' Bardi belongs. Accounts of the Bardi, especially of the battle which ended in the destruction of their house . and the expulsion of some members from the city, are found in various historical works. The text of Romola refers to Villani's history, and Dr. Guido Biagi points out that the source from which George Eliot probably obtained her first knowledge of the family was Ademollo's Marietta dei Ricci.

characters.name: Baccio (Hist.)
characters.desc: Painter, who assisted at the Bonfire of Vanities. Fra Bartolommeo (Baccio della Porta, 1475-1517). A distinguished Florentine painter, and an adherent of Savonarola, after whose death he assumed the Dominican habit. He painted the well-known portrait of Savonarola.

characters.name: Aurispa (Hist.)
characters.desc: A scholar who brought back manuscripts from Greece. Giovanni Aurispa (c. 1369-1460), a distinguished Italian humanist, at one time professor of Greek at Florence. He went to Greece and brought back more than 200 manuscripts of classical authors.

characters.name: Augustinians (Hist.)
characters.desc: A monastic order, called also the Frati Neri, or Black Brethren. The Augustinian Canons or Austin Canons, also called from the colour of their habit the Black Canons, or Black Brethren, who in the eleventh century adopted the Rule of St. Augustine. Their convent in Florence was the Convent and Church of Santo Spirito.

characters.name: Arrabbiati (Hist.)
characters.desc: The aristocratic party in Florence, bitter enemies of Savonarola and his party.

characters.name: Argiropulo, Giovanni (Hist.)
characters.desc: A Greek scholar under whom Bardo de' Bardi studied. A Greek who came to Italy about 1434; about 1456 he was teaching Greek in Florence. He died at Rome 1489.

characters.name: Antella, Lamberto dell' (Hist.)
characters.desc: A renegade Medicean whose arrest  "with a tell-tale letter on his person and a bitter rancour agains the Medici in his heart" leads to the discovery of the Medicean conspiracy.

characters.name: Alfonso, Crown Prince of Naples (Hist.)
characters.desc: Son of King Ferdinand, whom he succeeded on the throne of Naples in 1494.

characters.name: Alexander VI, Pope (Hist.)
characters.desc: The Pope, opposed by Savonarola. Rodrigo Borgia (1431-1503), made cardinal 1455, pope 1492-1503, father of Caesar and Lucretia Borgia.

characters.name: Manuzio, Aldo (Hist.)
characters.desc: A printer who wishes Bardo de' Bardi to give him the aid of his annotated manuscripts. Aldus Manutius (1450-1515) the great Venetian printer and humanist, who established himself in Venice in 1490 and began printing not long after that date.

characters.name: Albizzi (Hist.)
characters.desc: A prominent Florentine family, adherents of Savonarola.

characters.name: Alberti, Leon Battista (Hist.)
characters.desc: A famous writer, architect, sculptor, and painter, born at Genoa 1404, died at Rome 1472.

characters.name: Alberti (Hist.)
characters.desc: Member of the Arrabbiati. Piero Alberti, probably, who was a member of the Arrabbiati, and Gonfaloniere in 1497.

characters.name: Agli (Hist.)
characters.desc: A Florentine family whose houses were in Ognissanti.

characters.name: Acciajoli (Hist.)
characters.desc: A Florentine scholar who was "minded to take the cowl and join the community of San Marco". Zanobi Acciajoli (1461-1519 or 1520), who, influenced by Savonarola, entered San Marco in 1495. In 1518 he was made prefect of the Vatican, at Rome, and devoted himself to its library. The Acciajoli were a prominent Florentine family, many of whose members were Piagnoni, or followers of Savonarola.

characters.name: Taddeo
characters.desc: One of the Compagnacci.

characters.name: Sandro
characters.desc: Assistant to Nello the barber; a solemn dark-eyed youth.

characters.name: Nofri
characters.desc: Tessa's cross-grained stepfather who used to beat her.

characters.name: Ninna
characters.desc: Daughter of the contadina Tessa and Tito Melema.

characters.name: Nannina
characters.desc: Tessa's cousin, who married Gollo.

characters.name: Mariotto
characters.desc: A merry-eyed youth of seventeen, who joins in the sport of the mock marriages at the Peasants' Fair.

characters.name: Lollo
characters.desc: The conjurer's impish lad, who assists the conjurer at the Fierucola and later, as a prank, cuts the bonds of the old prisoner, thus releasing Baldassarre Calvo.

characters.name: Lillo
characters.desc: Small son of the contadina Tessa and Tito Melema. When as a child of three years old he runs away from home, he is found and taken home by Romola, who thus finds her husband's "other wife" and his children.

characters.name: Companies of Discipline (Real)
characters.desc: Participants in the procession of the Madonna de L'Impruneta, in Florence. "The mysterious-looking Companies of Discipline, bound by secret rules to self-chastisement, and devout praise, and special acts of piety; all wearing a garb which concealed the whole head and face except the eyes. Every one knew that these mysterious forms were Florentine citizens of various ranks... the garb of all was a complete shroud, and left no expression but that of fellowship." These were companies called Compagnie dei Disiplinati, or di Disciplina. They were thirty-eight in number, and drew their members from all ranks, high and low. Their duties included works of charity, marching in processions, and burial services.

characters.name: Arts of Florence (Real)
characters.desc: The 21 Guilds of Florence, described as taking part in the San Giovanni and Impruneta processions. Every Florentine citizen who wished to take any part in public life had to enroll in one of the Arti (Companies or Guilds). There were twenty-one of the guilds, divided into the Greater Arts, seven in number, and the fourteen Lesser Arts (at one time divided as the five Intermediate and the nine Lesser Arts). The seven Greater Arts were : the lawyers and notaries, the Calimala or dealers in foreign cloth, the guild of wool, the bankers and money-changers, the guild of silk or " Por Santa Maria ", the doctors and apothecaries, and the furriers and skinners. The Lesser Arts included the butchers, blacksmiths, shoe makers, builders, retailers of cloths, wine merchants, inn-keepers, tanners, provision dealers, saddlers, locksmiths, armourers, carpenters, and bakers.

characters.name: Art of the Moneychangers (Real)
characters.desc: A Florentine guild. The Arte del Cambio, one of the seven Greater Arts.

characters.name: Art of the Butchers (Real)
characters.desc: A Florentine guild. The Arte di Beccai, one of the fourteen Lesser Arts or Guilds.

characters.name: Arbues, Master (Real)
characters.desc: Grand Inquisitor of Aragon. Maestre Pedro Arbues, a canon of the cathedral of Saragasso, who was appointed Inquisitor by Torquemada in 1484. September 15, 1485, he was attacked as he was praying in the cathedral, and died a few days later as a result of his injuries. He was regarded as a martyr, and was canonized in 1867.

characters.name: Gollo
characters.desc: Husband of Tessa's cousin, Nannina.

characters.name: Gianni
characters.desc: Former owner of the little boat in which Romola puts to sea.

characters.name: Giannetta
characters.desc: Little mule belonging to Tessa.

characters.name: Domini Canes
characters.desc: "Hounds of the Lord"; name applied to the Dominicans; a play upon the name of the Order.

characters.name: Benedetto
characters.desc: A Jewish baby rescued by Romola in the plague-stricken village.

characters.name: Augustinian Monk
characters.desc: A monk who advised Tito to go to Florence instead of Rome.

characters.name: Arias
characters.desc: A stripling of fifteen, in Duke Silva's retinue, who is killed when the Moors take Bedmar.

characters.name: Aquila
characters.desc: A conversational bird of prey who instinctively appropriates from others morsels of information to use in his brilliant conversations.

characters.name: Annibal
characters.desc: Roldan's monkey, "a misanthropic monkey, grey and grim."

characters.name: Andres
characters.desc: A young Spaniard, Pepita's suitor.

characters.name: Aliquis
characters.desc: "who lets no attack on himself pass unnoticed"

characters.name: Alice
characters.desc: The Countess Czerlaski's buxom maid, who marries Mr. Bridmain, brother of the Countess.

characters.name: Alcharisi
characters.desc: Stage name of Daniel Deronda's mother, the Princess Halm-Eberstein.

characters.name: Adrastus
characters.desc: A busy essayist who writes on many subjects.

characters.name: Adolphe
characters.desc: An artist who, disappointed in love, consoles himself by love of his work.

places.name: Adelaide
places.desc: Ship.

places.name: "Apollo and the Razor"
places.desc: "Apollo and the Razor",Nello's barber-shop which serves as a meeting-place for literary and artistic Florentines. The original of Nello's shop was the shop of Burchiello, the barber-poet of Florence.

places.name: "Anchor Tavern"
places.desc: "Anchor Tavern",Tavern in St. Ogg's, frequented by sailors. This is the "Crown and Anchor," a small tavern in Bridge Street, Gainsborough.

places.name: Zecca, or Mint
places.desc: Zecca, or Mint,Its car figures in the San Giovanni procession in Florence. "Improved tast, with Cecca to help it, had devised for the magnificent Zecca a triumphal car like a pyramidal catafalque, with ingenious wheels warranted o turn all corners easily. Round the base were living figures of saints and angels arrayed in sculpturesque fashion; and on the summit, at the height of thirty feet, well bound to an iron rod and holding an iron cross also firmly infixed, stood a living representative of St. John the Baptist." The Mint occupied the site of the present Post Office, and the old Mint, the Zecca Vecchia, was behind the church of Santa Croce, but this was given up in 1252 when the new Mint was built.

places.name: Pippo's Shop
places.desc: Pippo's Shop,Shop where Tessa buys sweetmeats for her children.

places.name: Piccola, Via
places.desc: Piccola, Via,A little street in Florence, beyond San Ambrogio, where Tessa and her children live after they move from San Giorgio.

places.name: Bertucce, or Baboons, Hostelry of the
places.desc: Bertucce, or Baboons, Hostelry of the,Tavern in Florence near which Tito rescues Tessa from the cerretano or conjurer on Mid summer Day.

places.name: Bardi House
places.desc: Bardi House,A house on the Via de' Bardi, belonging to the Neri, in which Romola and her blind father lived. A house on the Via de' Bardi, which, like Romola's, has a loggia on the roof, has been pointed out as the one which George Eliot may have had in mind in describing Romola's house.

places.name: Abderahman's Tower
places.desc: Abderahman's Tower,Tower in the Castle of Bedmar where the astrologer Sephardo has his study.

places.name: Abbey
places.desc: Abbey,The name of the Donnithorne mansion, at Donnithorne Chase.

places.name: Pyramid of Vanites (Real)
places.desc: The great pile of gauds and vanities brought together for the bonfire of Vanities in the Piazza della Signoria, Florence. "There were tapestries and brocades of immodest design, pictures and sculptures held too likely to incite to vice; there were boards and tables for all sorts of games, playing-cards along with the blocks for printing them, dice, and other apparatus for gambling ; there were worldly music-books, and musical instruments in all the pretty varieties of lute, drum, cymbal, and trumpet ; there were masks and masquerading-dresses used in the old carnival shows; there were handsome copies of Ovid, Boccaccio, Petrarca, Polci, and other books of a vain or impure sort; there were all the implements of feminine vanity."

places.name: Viareggio (Real)
places.desc: Viareggio (Real),Little fishing village on the Mediterranean. This is the present coast resort of Viareggio in Tuscany, 13 miles west of Lucca.

places.name: Venice (Real)
places.desc: Venice (Real),At the time of Romola the Republic of Venice was one of the five great powers of Italy. Its Great Council, created in 1189, furnished the model for the Great Council of Florence advocated by Savonarola.

places.name: Trespiano (Real)
places.desc: Trespiano (Real),A village where old maso is to wait for Romola when she plans to leave Florence. Trespiano, a village a few miles north of Florence, on the road to Bologna.

places.name: Thessalonica (Real)
places.desc: Thessalonica (Real),One of the cities in which Tito Melema and Baldassarre Calvo resided. A city of ancient Greece, now Salonika.

places.name: Tetto de' Pisani (Real)
places.desc: Tetto de' Pisani (Real),A projecting roof on the west side of Piazza della Signoria, Florence, built by prisoners form Pisa about 1364. It was torn down about 1865.

places.name: Stinche (Real)
places.desc: Stinche (Real),The largest prison in Florence, in which, after the scene in the Rucellai Gardens, where he is denied by Tito, Baldassarre Calvo is imprisoned. The old prison of the Stinche, which was demolished in the nineteenth century, stood on the present site of the Accademia Filarmonica and the Teatro Pagliano. It was built at the end of the thirteenth century, and took its name from the fact that prisoners taken at the siege of Castello delle Stinche were confined there in 1304

places.name: Spini Palace (Real)
places.desc: Spini Palace (Real),"The great house with the loggia, over the bridge of the Santa Trinita" The Palazzo Spini, now usually called the Palazzo Ferroni, dates from the beginning of the fourteenth century. It became the property of the Ferroni family in the eighteenth century.

places.name: Spedale degl' Innocenti (Foundling Hospital) (Real)
places.desc: Spedale degl' Innocenti (Foundling Hospital) (Real),The Spedale degli Innocenti on the northeast side of the Piazza dell' Annunziata, was begun about 1419 by Brunelleschi, and completed 1451.

places.name: Signoria, Piazza della (Real)
places.desc: Signoria, Piazza della (Real),The great square of Florence, scene of the San Giovanni festival, of the Bonfire of Vanities, of the proposed Trial by Fire, and finally of Savonarola's execution. "The Piazza della Signoriathat famous piazza, where stood then, and stand now, the massive turreted Palace of the People, called the Palazzo Vecchio, and the spacious Loggia, built by Orcagna--the scene of all grand State ceremonial. The picturesque Piazza della Signoria, the centre of Florentine life and ceremony, is of ancient construction and has preserved its present aspect since the fourteenth century. In the time of Romola it was called Piazza della Signoria. Later names were Piazza del Granduca and Piazza Nazionale, but it has now resumed its earlier name. A bronze tablet now marks the spot where the gallows upon which Savonarola was executed was erected.

places.name: Signa (Real)
places.desc: Signa (Real),Location of the French camp. The little town of Signa about eight miles from Florence, founded by the Florentines in 1377, to command the east end of the Gonfolino.

places.name: Siena (Real)
places.desc: Siena (Real),Town to which Tito Melema is commissioned to go after offering to furnish the evidence of another Medicean plot. Siena, a city in Tuscany thirty one miles southeast of Florence.

places.name: Scala Palace (Real)
places.desc: Scala Palace (Real),The handsome palace close to the Porta Pinit where Bartolommeo Scala lived; "now known as the Casa Gherardesca." The Casa Gherardesca on the Via de' Pinti, originally built for Bartolommeo Scala, passed later to Alessandro de' Medici, Archbishop of Florence, afterwards Pope Leo XI, and eventually became the property of the Gherardesca family.

places.name: Scala, Via della (Real)
places.desc: Scala, Via della (Real),Street in Florence where the Rucellai Garden is located. The Via della Scala, still so called, took its name from the foundling hospital which had been established there by Cione di Lapo Pollini and placed under the direction of the hospital of Santa Maria della Scala, in Siena.

places.name: Santa Maria Novella, Church of (Real)
places.desc: Santa Maria Novella, Church of (Real),Church in Florence, the facade of which had been completed at the expense of Bernardo Rucellai. Santa Maria Novella was begun by the Dominicans about 1279. The facade, begun in 1350, was completed 1456-70. The richest patrons of the church were the Rucellai.

places.name: Santa Lucia, Church of (Real)
places.desc: Santa Lucia, Church of (Real),A small church near the Bardi house, in Florence. This is the small church of Santa Lucia dei Magnoli, in the Via de' Bardi, found 1078.

places.name: Santa Felicita, Church of (Real)
places.desc: Santa Felicita, Church of (Real),A church in Florence close to the Via de' Bardi, near which Fra Luca gives Tito Melema the message from Baldassarre Calvo. Santa Felicita, a church south of the Ponte Vecchio, on the little Piazza Santa Felicita, is a church of very ancient origin, consecrated 1059, restored 1736.

places.name: Santa Croce, Piazza de (Real)
places.desc: Santa Croce, Piazza de (Real),The square in Florence where the public notice of the Trial by Fire, which Tito Melema reads and explains to the crowd, is posted. The Piazza di Santa Croce, in front of the Franciscan church of Santa Croce from which it takes its name, was formerly the scene of tournaments and of the favourite Florentine game of Calcio.

places.name: Santa Croce, Church of (Real)
places.desc: Santa Croce, Church of (Real),The church in Florence in which Romola de' Bardi and Tito Melema are betrothed and in which later Bardo de' Bardi is buried. The Franciscan, Fra Francesco di Puglia, preaches his sermons against Savonarola in Santa Croce. "The long dark mass of Santa Croce, where we buried our famous dead, laying the laurel on their cold brows, and fanning them with the breath of praise and of banners. But Santa Croce had no spire then." The Church of Santa Croce, on the Piazza di Santa Croce, begun in 1294, completed in 1442, was built for the Franciscans in the form of a Latin cross. The facade is a nineteenth century addition. The number of famous dead buried there made it the Pantheon of Florence.

places.name: San Stefano (Real)
places.desc: San Stefano (Real),The church in Florence to the steps of which the starving Baldassarre Calvo is carried when Romola succours him. The Church of Santo Stefano, supposed to have been founded in 790, is now known as the Church of SS. Stefano e Cecilia, the Cecilia having been added in 1783 when a church of that name was suppressed.

places.name: San Spirito (Real)
places.desc: San Spirito (Real),Convent and church of the Augustinians in Florence. The Augustinian Church of Santo Spirito, on the Piazza Santo Spirito, which was attached to the monastery, was originally built in 1250 and twice rebuilt during the fifteenth century.

places.name: San Sebastiano, Via (Real)
places.desc: San Sebastiano, Via (Real),Street in Florence along which Tito Melema goes to the Piazza dell' Anunziata on the evening of the Fierucola. This is the present Via Gino Capponi.

places.name: San Pulinari (Real)
places.desc: San Pulinari (Real),Church in Florence where Tessa became separated from her mother in the crowd. The Church of San Pulinari was near the Loggia dell' Orcagna.

places.name: San Miniato, Hill of (Real)
places.desc: San Miniato, Hill of (Real),A famous hill overlooking Florence from the south, from which, in the Proem of Romola, the spirit of the ancient Florentine views the modern city and where, in the story, Baldassarre Calvo talks with Romola and tells her that Tito Melema has "another wife". San Miniato is a hill south of Florence from which a particularly fine view of the city is obtained. It is crowned by the Church of San Miniato.

places.name: San Miniato, Convent of (Real)
places.desc: San Miniato, Convent of (Real),Convent, in the hospital of which Baldassarre Calvo is cared for when he is helpless. This was the ancient Benedictine monastery of San Miniato, connected with the Church of San Miniato on the hill of the same name, called after the martyr San Miniato who was buried there. During a later plague than the one mentioned in Romola the abbey was used as a lazaretto.

places.name: San Martino (Real)
places.desc: San Martino (Real),A cloth-producing section of Florence. —Guido Biagi in his edition of Romola points out that San Martino was not properly a quarter but merely a certain length of street. The old Via San Martino now forms part of the Via Dante Alighier.

places.name: San Marco, Piazza di (Real)
places.desc: San Marco, Piazza di (Real),Square in Florence before the Church of San Marco; the scene of Savonarola's open-air sermon to the crowd, 27th February, 1498. The Piazza di San Marco takes its name from the adjoining church and convent of San Marco. Its principal associations are with Savonarola and the Dominicans, but it was also a favourite playground for the popular game of Palla e Maglio.

places.name: San Marco, Convent and Church of (Real)
places.desc: San Marco, Convent and Church of (Real),The Dominican monastery of which Savonarola is Prior. "San Marco . . . the long corridors fined with cells—corridors where Fra Angelico's frescoes, delicate as the rainbow on the melting cloud, startled the unaccustomed eye here and there, as if they had been sudden reflections cast from an ethereal world, where the Madonna sat crowned in her radiant glory, and the Divine infant looked forth with perpetual promise." Romola's brother, the Dominican Fra Luca, dies at San Marco, and it is there, at his death bed, that Romola first sees Savonarola. When Bernardo del Nero is arrested Romola goes to San Marco to beg Savonarola for her godfather's life, and later Tito Melema goes to San Marco to obtain the letter by means of which he hopes to ruin Savonarola. After the proposed Trial by Fire, San Marco is attacked by the mob and Savonarola is arrested there. The famous Monastery, with the adjoining Church of San Marco, on the Piazza San Marco, was founded 1290 by the Silveetrini, and later, under Cosimo the Elder, was transferred to the Dominicans. In the fifteenth century the monastery was restored by Michelozzo and was decorated with frescoes by Fra Angelico da Fiesole. It was suppressed in 1867, and is now a museum. Several of the historical characters in Romola, including Pico delta Mirandola and Angelo Poliziano, are buried in the church.

places.name: San Lorenzo (Real)
places.desc: San Lorenzo (Real),The church in Florence where Savonarola preached during Lent, 1492. The ancient Church of San Lorenzo, consecrated by St. Ambrose in 393, was the first cathedral of Florence. Brunelleschi made the designs for its restoration in the first half of the fifteenth century. Some of Savonarola's most important sermons were preached in San Lorenzo.

places.name: San Giovanni, Piazza de (Real)
places.desc: San Giovanni, Piazza de (Real),Square in Florence, where Nello's barber-shop is located. The Piazza di San Giovanni, which took its name from the Battistero, or Church of San Giovanni Battista, adjoins the Piazza del Duomo. One of the oldest squares in Florence, it was the scene of the great religious festivals.

places.name: San Giovanni, Festa of (Real)
places.desc: San Giovanni, Festa of (Real),The great summer festival of Florence, of which city San Giovanni was the patron saint; held on Midsummer Day (St. John's Day). "The day of San Giovanni . . . A day of peculiar rejoicing to Florence . . . Ushered in by a vigil duly kept in strict old Florentine fashion, with much dancing, with much street jesting, and perhaps with not a little stone-throwing and windowbreaking, but emphatically with certain street sights such as could only be provided by a city which held in its service a clever Cecca, engineer and architect, valuable alike in sieges and shows." Tito Melema, after watching the San Giovanni procession, renews his acquaintance with the contadina Tessa, and after returning from an excursion with her sees Fra Luca, who gives him a letter from his lost foster-father Baldassarre Calvo.

places.name: San Giorgio, Hill of (Real)
places.desc: San Giorgio, Hill of (Real),A hill behind the Via de' Bardi where Baldassarre Calvo finds a lodging in Tessa's house, and where he tries unsuccessfully to kill Tito Melema.

places.name: San Gallo, Via (Real)
places.desc: San Gallo, Via (Real),One of the streets in Florence where Romola looks for Tessa. The Via San Gallo continues Via dei Ginori northeast to the Piazza Cavour (Piazza della Porta a San Gallo).

places.name: San Gallo (Real)
places.desc: San Gallo (Real),A suburb just outside the San Gallo gate of Florence, where Tessa and her children are left stranded after Tito Melema's death.

places.name: San Gaggio, Church of (Real)
places.desc: San Gaggio, Church of (Real),Church outside the gate of San Piero wher the image of the Madonna dell' Impruneta was deposited before being brought into Florence. The Monastery and Church of San Gaggio, outside the gate of San Piero Gattolino (later Porta Romana), founded 1345.

places.name: San Casciano (Real)
places.desc: San Casciano (Real),A town near Florence, falsely given as a proposed stopping-place of the Cardinal of Naples. San Casciano, in Tuscany, about ten miles southeast of Florence.

places.name: San Ambrogio (Real)
places.desc: San Ambrogio (Real),Church in Florence near which Romola finds the run away Lillo. The Church of Sant' Ambrogio, on the Piazza Sant' Ambrogio, was built in the tenth century with a convent for Benedictines, the first convent for nuns in Florence.

places.name: Rucellai Gardens (Real)
places.desc: Rucellai Gardens (Real),Scene of the political supper given by Bernardo Rucellai at which Baldassarre Calvo tries to reveal Tito Melema's deceit and ingratitude, but breaks down before he can prove his charge. The Rucellai Gardens, or, Orti Oricellari, a famous garden in the Via della Scala where in the time of Bernardo Rucellai, after the death of Lorenzo de' Medici, the meetings of the Platonic Academy in Florence were held.

places.name: Rovezzano (Real)
places.desc: Rovezzano (Real),A village near Florence, on the road which leads from the Porta alla Croce.

places.name: Romagna (Real)
places.desc: Romagna (Real),Section of Italy where Piero de' Medici was trying to gather forces in 1497.

places.name: Prato, The (Real)
places.desc: Prato, The (Real),"A large, open space within the walls, where the Florentine youth played at their favourite Calcio." A large triangular field formerly just within the Porta al Prato, where the Florentines used to play games and where the tiltings took place.

places.name: Prato (Real)
places.desc: Prato (Real),A town near Florence where the doctor Maestro Tacco once lived. Prato, ten miles northwest of Florence, on the Bisenzio, and affluent of the Arno.

places.name: Porta Santa Croce (Real)
places.desc: Porta Santa Croce (Real),Gate in Florence near which Tessa and her children live. The Porta alla Croce was built about 1287 under the direction of Arnolfo. The space in which it stands is now the Piazza Beccaria.

places.name: Porta San Piero (Real)
places.desc: Porta San Piero (Real),The gate of Florence "that looks toward Siena and Rome". The Porta San Piero Gattolino, now called the Porta Romana.

places.name: Porta San Gallo (Real)
places.desc: Porta San Gallo (Real),Gate by which Tito Melema plans to make his final departure from Florence. The Porta San Gallo, at the end of the Via di San Gallo, was begun in 1284.

places.name: Porta San Frediano (Real)
places.desc: Porta San Frediano (Real),The gate by which Charles VIII enters Florence. The Porta San Frediano was erected 1332. It was the gate looking toward Pisa, and through it Charles VIII entered 17th November, 1494.

places.name: Porta Rossa (Real)
places.desc: Porta Rossa (Real),Street in Florence by which Tito Melema and Tessa go to Ognissanti, during the San Giovanni fests. Via Porta Rossa, so named from a gate in the second circuit of walls built of brick, is a street which leads westward from Via Calzaiuoli.

places.name: Porta Pinti (Real)
places.desc: Porta Pinti (Real),Gate in Florence near which Bartolommeo Scala lived. The gate at the end of the Borgo Pinti (Via de' Pinti), erected about the end of the thirteenth century. It was pulled down in the nineteenth century.

places.name: Por' Santa Maria (Real)
places.desc: Por' Santa Maria (Real),Street in Florence, near which Romola comes upon the starving Baldassarre Calvo. The Por' Santa Maria, so named from a gate in the first circuit of the old walls, leads northward from the Ponte Vecchio.

places.name: Por' del Prato (Real)
places.desc: Por' del Prato (Real),Gate in Florence beyond which Tessa's mother and step-father live. This is the Porta al Prato, formerly a part of the walls, at the end of the Via del Prato. Guido Biagi points out that the form of the name used by George Eliot, Por del Prato, is incorrect. It was called al Prato because just within it was a large field.

places.name: Ponte Vecchio (Real)
places.desc: Ponte Vecchio (Real),The bridge across the Arno in Florence, from which Tito Melema leaps when pursued by the mob. The oldest bridge in Florence, said to date originally from Roman times; several times demolished, it was finally rebuilt by Taddeo Gaddi in 1345.

places.name: Ponte Santa Trinita (Real)
places.desc: Ponte Santa Trinita (Real),Bridge across the Arno, in Florence, the first one passed by Tito Melema when he tries to escape the mob by swimming. The Ponte Santa Trinita, one of the most beautiful bridges in Italy, was built in 1252, and rebuilt in 1567-70 by Ammanati. It takes its name from the Church of Santa Trinita nearby.

places.name: Ponte Rubaconte, or Ponte alle Grazie (Real)
places.desc: Ponte Rubaconte, or Ponte alle Grazie (Real),Bridge across the Arno, In Florence, near Romola's house. The Ponte alle Grazie was built in 1237 for Rubaconte da Mandella. It was formerly called the Ponte Rubaconte, its other name, alle Grazie, coming from the chapel of Santa Maria delle Grazie, on the right bank. It was modernized in 1874, when the old houses on the bridge were demolished.

places.name: Ponte alle Carraja (Real)
places.desc: Ponte alle Carraja (Real),Bridge across the Arno, in Florence, the last one passed by Tito when he tries to escape the mob by swimming. The Ponte alla Carraia, then called Ponte Nuovo, was built 1218-20 at the expense of the Frati Umiliati. It was destroyed by an inundation in 1333, restored in 1337, partially rebuilt in 1559, and widened in 1867.

places.name: Pistoja (Real)
places.desc: Pistoja (Real),Town where Romola breaks her journey when returning to Florence. Pistoja, or Pistoia, is an ancient town in Tuscany, on the Ombrone, twenty-one miles northwest of Florence.

places.name: Pisa (Real)
places.desc: Pisa (Real),A city conquered by Florence, which had rebelled. Pisa, a city forty-nine miles west of Florence. Captured by Florence in 1406, it reasserted its independence in 1494 at the time of the visit of Charles VIII of France, and was in a state of rebellion during most of the time of Romola.

places.name: Pietra (Real)
places.desc: Pietra (Real),The village near which Romola's flight from Florence is arrested by her encounter with Savonarola. A village on the road to Bologna about two miles north of Florence.

places.name: Peretola (Real)
places.desc: Peretola (Real),A village near Florence. A village about three miles from Florence, beyond the Porta al Prato.

places.name: Palazzo Vecchio (Real)
places.desc: Palazzo Vecchio (Real),The home of the Gonfaloniere and Signoria, the seat of the government of Florence. Savonarola is imprisoned here. The Palazzo Vecchio, on the Piazza della Signoria, was befun in 1298 from Arnolfo di Cambio's designs and completed and extended at later dates. Until 1532 it was the seat of the government of Florence, and then for awhile the palace of Cosimo I. Since 1871 it has been a civic building. Its earlier name was Palazzo del Popolo, dei Signori, or della Signoria, and Guido Biagi points out that it could not have been called Palazzo Vecchio in the time of Romola, as that name was not used until 1550.

places.name: Palagio, Via del (Real)
places.desc: Palagio, Via del (Real),Street in Florence by which Romola and Monna Brigida return after the latter has given up her "vanities" to the Piagnoni. The old Via del Palagio del Podesta now forms the first part of the Via Ghibellina as far as the Via Giuseppe Verdi.

places.name: Palace of the Via Larga (Real)
places.desc: Palace of the Via Larga (Real),The home of the Medici before their expulsion from Florence, where Charles VIII is lodged after his entry into Florence. This is the Palazzo Medici (sometimes called Palazzo Riccardi after its later owners) in the Via Cavour (formerly Via Larga). It was erected about 1444-52 by Michelozzo for Cosimo Pater Patriae. It is now a government building occupied by the prefecture.

places.name: Padua (Real)
places.desc: Padua (Real),Padua, a city of northern Italy, which at the time of Romola was under Venetian rule.

places.name: Oriuola, Via dell' (Real)
places.desc: Oriuola, Via dell' (Real),Street in Florence. The Via dell' Orivola (Oriuola) leads from the Duomo in the direction of Porta alla Croce. It was so named in the fourteenth century because the first Florentine clock (oriulo or orologico) was made there, 1353.

places.name: Orcagna's (or Orgagna's) Loggia (Real)
places.desc: Orcagna's (or Orgagna's) Loggia (Real),The spacious loggia on the Piazza della Signoria, Florence, in which the Franciscans and Dominicans were placed at the time of the Trial by Fire. Orgagna's Loggia is the beautiful arcade near the Palazzo Vecchio which is usually called the Loggia de' Lanzi (from the Swiss lancers posted there under Cosimo I), although the name Loggia dell' Orgagna is also used. Its earlier names were Loggia dei Signori or Loggia dei Priori; at the time of the Trial by Fire, it was called Loggia dei Signori. It was ordered by the General Council of Florence in 1356, and though perhaps designed by Orgagna, was not built until 1376-92, several years after Orgagna's death.

places.name: Oltrarno (Real)
places.desc: Oltrarno (Real),The section of Florence in which Romola lived. Oltrarno, that is, the part of the city beyond, or on the south side of, the Arno, one of the four quarters into which Florence was divided in 1342.

places.name: Ognissanti, Piazza d' (Real)
places.desc: Ognissanti, Piazza d' (Real),Place in Florence where Tito Melema and Tessa rest on their way to the Prato. This is the square now called the Piazza Manin.

places.name: Ognissanti (Real)
places.desc: Ognissanti (Real),The street in Florence where the dyers carried on their trade. This was the Borgo Ognissanti, near the monastery of Ognissanti, where for several centuries the Frati Umiliati had carried on an extensive industry in woollen manufacture and such allied trades as dyeing, etc.

places.name: Ognissanti (Real)
places.desc: Ognissanti (Real),Monastery of the Frati Umiliati in Florence. The suppressed Minorite monastery of Ognissanti, on the east side of the Piazza Manin, now a barracks. It was occupied from 1256 by the Frati Umiliati or Humbled Brethren, workers in the wool trade. In 1554 it was ceded to the Franciscans.

places.name: Nauplia (Real)
places.desc: Nauplia (Real),The port from which Tito Melema and Baldassarre Calvo had sailed on their last voyage. A Greek port, at the head of the Gulf of Nauplia.

places.name: Mugello (Real)
places.desc: Mugello (Real),A region from which the contadini come to Florence for the San Giovanni festa. The Mugello, a district northeast of Florence.

places.name: Mozzi, Piazza de' (Real)
places.desc: Mozzi, Piazza de' (Real),Piazza in Florence at the end of the Via de' Bardi. The Piazza de' Mozzi, names after the Mozzi family, bankers to the popes, extends from the Via de' Bardi to the Ponte alle Grazie.

places.name: Morello, Mount (Real)
places.desc: Morello, Mount (Real),A hill near Florence. A mountain north of Florence.

places.name: "Moor, The (Real)
places.desc: "Moor, The (Real),A druggist's shop which pretends to rival Nello's barber shop as a resort for the eruditi. The Pharmacia del Moro, or del Saracino (both names were used), which had a Moor's head for a sign, was one of the oldest and best known in Florence, and by the beginning of the sixteenth century was already established at the Canto alla Paglia, at the corner of the Borgo San Lorenzo and the Piazza San Giovanni. It belonged to the Grazzini family, and among the members of that family who practised there was the poet Anton Francesco Grazzini, called Il Lasco (1503- ).84

places.name: Mercato Vecchio, or Old Market (Real)
places.desc: Mercato Vecchio, or Old Market (Real),The important centre of Florentine popular life, where Tito Melema on his first day in Florence hears the populace discuss the news of Lorenzo de' Medici's death, and first sees Tessa. "A broad piazza, known to the elder Florentine writers as the Mercato Vecchio, or the Old Market. This piazza, though it had been the scene of a provision market from time immemorial, and may, perhaps, says fond imagination, be the very spot to which the Fesulean ancestors of the Florentines descended from their high fastness to traffic with the rustic population of the valley, had not been shunned as a place of residence by Florentine wealth. In the early decades of the fifteenth century, which was now near its end, the Medici and other powerful families of the popolani grassi, or commercial nobility, had their houses there, not perhaps finding their ears much offended by the loud roar of mingled dialects, or their eyes much shocked by the butchers' stalls, which the old poet Antonio Pucci accounts a chief glory, or dignita, of a market that, in his esteem, eclipsed the markets of all the earth beside." The Mercato Vecchio, which in the time of Romola was the "heart of Florence" and the centre of Florentine commerce, was the oldest part of Florence. It no longer exists, having been swept away 1885-9 to make way for the modern Piazza Vittorio Emanuele. Its life and manners are described by many of the older Florentine writers, notably Antonio Pucci and Franco Sacchetti, the latter of whom has been called the "Echo of the Old Market".

places.name: Medicean Library (Real)
places.desc: Medicean Library (Real),The library of Lorenzo de' Medici, which Savonarola acquired for the Convent of San Marco. The most important part of the Medicean Library of the Dominicans of San Marco is now preserved in the great Biblioteca Medicea-Laurenziana, of Florence.

places.name: Marzocco (Real)
places.desc: Marzocco (Real),The stone lion, emblem of the Florentine Republic. The Marzocco, or stone lion, was set up in various parts of Florence. The one which was in the Piazza della Signoria at the time of Romola was by Donatello, and represented a lion seated on his haunches with the right forepaw resting on a shield on which the Florentine lily was carved. This has been replaced by a bronze cast and the original moved to the Museo Nazionale.

places.name: Martelli, Via de' (Real)
places.desc: Martelli, Via de' (Real),Street in Florence by which the syndics return from their interview with Charles VIII in the Via Larga. Via de' Martelli is a short street leading from the Piazza del Duomo to the Via Cavour (formerly Via Larga). Its earlier name of Via degli Spadai was changed to Martelli, from the houses of the Martelli family.

places.name: Maglio, Via del (Real)
places.desc: Maglio, Via del (Real),Street in Florence through which Romola and Monna Brigida have to take a roundabout way to San Marco because of the crowd of the Fierucola. The street formerly called Via del Maglio from the popular game Del Maglio played there by the young Florentines, is now the Via Lamarmora extending northward from San Marco.

places.name: Lunigiana (Real)
places.desc: Linigiana (Real),The region where the prisoners brought to Florence by the French had been captured. A picturesque region of Central Italy, including the lower valley of the Magra and the mountains to the west.

places.name: Lung Arno (Real)
places.desc: Lung Arno (Real),Quai along the Arno is Florence, where on the day of his betrothal Tito Melema first sees that Tessa is following him.

places.name: Loggia de' Cerchi (Real)
places.desc: Loggia de' Cerchi (Real),Arcade in Florence under which Bratti finds Tito Melema sleeping. The Loggia dei Cerchi, which in the fifteenth century was an a.rcade near the houses of the famous Cerchi family, is now enclosed, forming the lower story of a house at the comer of the Via dei Cerchi and the Via de' Cimatori. Parts of the columns of the Loggia showing the Arms of the Cerchi can still be seen.

places.name: Libraj, Via de' (Real)
places.desc: Libraj, Via de' (Real),Street in Florence where Tessa meets the young Piagnoni who demand her necklace for the Bonfire of Vanities. The street formerly called Via de' Libraj is that part of the present Via del Proconsolo between the Borgo degli Albizi and the Piazza San Firenze.

places.name: Leghorn (Real)
places.desc: Leghorn (Real),The Italian port to which the French aid for Florence at the time of the famine is sent. Leghorn, on the Mediterranea, about fifty miles southwest of Florence.

places.name: Larga, Via (Real)
places.desc: Larga, Via (Real),Street in Florence where the Palace of the Medici is located. The old Via Larga (now part of the Via Cavour) took its name both from its size and from the many rich palaces which it contained.

places.name: Impreneta (L'), Church of (Real)
places.desc: Impruneta (L'), Church of (Real),A church six miles from Florence which contained the shrine of the sacred image of the unseen Madonna dell' Impruneta. The Church of Santa Maria dell' Impruneta, founded by the Buondelmonte family, consecrated in 1054, and rebuilt about 1470. One of the chapels contains the miracle working statue of the Virgin. This church, in the village of Impruneta, is famous for its Della Robbias.

places.name: Hospital of San Matteo (Real)
places.desc: Hospital of San Matteo (Real),Hospital in Florence which Romola visits during the famine. The Ospedale de San Matteo, in the Piazza di San Marco, founded in the fourteenth century. It is now the Academia delle Belle Arti.

places.name: Hospital for Poor Travellers (Real)
places.desc: Hospital for Poor Travellers (Real),A convent hospital outside the Porta Santa Croce, Florence, to which Piero di Cosimo directs Baldassarre Calvo after the latter escapes from the French soldiers. In the fifteenth century Florence had many hospitals of both types, those for the care of the sick and those for the entertainment of poor travellers. At least one of the second type was to be foun dnear each gate of the city.

places.name: Guicciardini, Via (Real)
places.desc: Guicciardini, Via (Real),Street in the Oltrarno quarter of Florence, near one corner of which Tito Melema is first seen by Fra Luca. This street, which leads south from the Ponte Vecchio, is named from the houses of the Guicciardini families there. At an earlier date it was called the Borgo di Piazza.

places.name: Gualfonda, Via (Real)
places.desc: Gualfonda, Via (Real),Street in Florence where the artist Piero di Cosimo lives. The Via Gualfonda (now spelled Valfonda) extends from the Piazza della Stazione to the Viale Filippo Strozzi. George Eliot follows the authority of Bottari's foot note to Vasari in locating Piero di Cosimo's dwelling there, but Guido Biagi points out that that is an error, as Piero di Cosimo lived, according to his own declaration in the Rent Bolls of 1498, in the Via della Scala. (See Biagi ed. of Romola, vol. i, p. 237.)

places.name: Garbo (Real)
places.desc: Garbo (Real),A cloth-producing quarter of Florence. In chapter XXX this is mentioned as the Via del Garbo where Baldassarre Calvo buys a book. Guido Biagi, in his edition of Romola points out that the Garbo was not properly a quarter, but merely a certain length of street, corresponding to that portion of the present Via della Condotta between the Via Calzaiuoli and the Piazzetta delle Farine. The woollen cloth manufactured in the Via del Garbo was a finer quality than that from San Martino, the other cloth-producing section. (See Romola, Biagi ed. vol. 1, p. 11.)

places.name: Fosso, Via del (Real)
places.desc: Fosso, Via del (Real),Street in Florence along which Baldassaree Calvo goes to purchase a knife at Niccolo Caparra's shop. This was the Via del Fosso (now a part of the Via de' Benci) which extended from the Ponte alle Grazie to the Borgo S. Croce. A part of the present Via Giuseppe Verdi which continues the Via de' Benci to the north was also called the Via del Fosso.

places.name: Florence (Real)
places.desc: Florence (Real),Scene of the principal events in Romola. Many Florentine localities and buildings are mentioned in the novel. All of these which have any part, however small, in the plot of the story, are entered separately in their alphabetical places in the Dictionary, and the fuller information, including the historical notes, is given under these separate entries. The following list will show at a glance what localities in Florence and the immediate vicinity are mentioned. For fuller information, consult the separate entires in the main alphabet. As the form of name given in the following list is in every case that used by George Eliot, some places are given under their English names, others under the Italian. Arno (River); Bardi House; Bogoli, Hill of; Bridges: Ponte alla Carraja, Ponte Rubaconte, or, Ponte alle Grazie, Ponte Santa Trinita, Ponte Vecchio; Canto di Paglia; Churches and Convents: Annunziata, Badia, Baptistery, or, San Giovanni Battista, Duomo, or, Santa Maria del Fiore, Ognissanti, San Ambrogio, San Gaggio (outside the Porta Romana), San Giovanni, San Lorenzo, San Marco, San Miniato, San Pulinari, San Spirito, San Stefano, Santa Croce, Santa Felicita, Santa Lucia, Santa Maria del Fiore (Duomo), Santa Maria Novella; Dante's House; Fiesole (three miles northeast of Florence); Fiesole, Dominican Monastery at (San Domenico de Fiesole); Gates: Por' del Prato, Porta Pinti, Porta San Frediano, Porta San Gallo, Porta San Piero, Porta Santa Croce, Giotto's Campanile; Hospitals: Hospital for Poor Travellers (outside Porta Santa Croce), Hospital of San Matteo, Spedale degl' Innocenti (Foundling Hospital); Loggia de' Cerchi; Loggia Orcagna's; Marcato Vecchio, or, Old Market; Oltrarno; Orcagna's Loggia; Palaces (including public buildings): Bargello, Medici (referred to as "Palace of the Via Larga"), Pitti, Scala (Casa Gherardesca), Spini, Vecchio; Piazza; Prato, The; Rucellai Gardens; San Giorgio, Hill of; San Martino; San Miniato, Hill of; Squares: Piazza d' Ognissanti, Piazza de' Mozzi, Piazza del Duomo, Piazza dell' Annunziata, Piazza della Signoria, Piazza di San Giovanni, Piazza di San Marco, Piazza di Santa Croce; Stinche (Prison); Streets: Borgo de' Greci, Borgo degli Albizzi, Borgo di San Lorenzo, Borgo la Croce, Borgo Pinti, Borgo Santa Croce, Calimara, Corso dogle Adimari, Ferravecchi, Lung Arno, Ognissanti, Por' Santa Maria, Porta Rossa, Via de' Bardi, Via de' Benci, Via de' Cerretani, Via de' Febbrai, Via de' Libraj, Via de' Martelli, Via del Cocomero, Via del Fosso, Via del Garbo, Via del Maglio, Via del Palagio, Via dell' Oriuolo, Via della Scala, Via Gualponda, Via Guicciardini, Via Larga, Via San Gallo, Via San Sebastiono; Tetto de' Pisani

places.name: Fivizzano (Real)
places.desc: Fivizzano (Real),Town near which the French Soldiers had taken Baldassarre Calvo prisoner. A small town 34 miles northwest of Lucca, Italy.

places.name: Fiesole, Dominican Monastery at (Real)
places.desc: Fiesole, Dominican Monastery at (Real),Place to which the sick monk, Fra Luca, is carried from San Marco. This is the Dominican monastery at San Domenico de Fiesole, founded 1405, where Fra Angelico da Fiesole lived before his removal to San Marco, Florence.

places.name: Fiesole (Real)
places.desc: Fiesole (Real),"Fiesole with its crown of monastic walls and cypresses." Town about three miles northeast of Florence.

places.name: Ferravecchi (Real)
places.desc: Ferravecchi (Real),Street in Florence where Bratti Ferravecchi had his second-hand shop. The Via de' (or tra') Ferravecchi was a street leading out of the Mercato Vecchio, which took its name from the fact that the dealers in old iron lived there. At the time when the mercato Vecchio was swept away, the Ferravecchi became part of the Via degli Strozzi.

places.name: Ferrara (Real)
places.desc: Ferrara (Real),Savonarola's birthplace and early home were in "brilliant Ferrara". Ferrara, thirty miles northeast of Bologna, was the capital of the House of Este. In Savonarola's time it was a powerful city of about 100,000 inhabitants, and its court was one of the most famous and magnificent in Italy.

places.name: Febbrai, Via de' (Real)
places.desc: Febbrai, Via de' (Real),A street in Florence, near the narrow entrance to which some apprentices engage in stone throwing during the Fierucola. This is the short Via Fibbiai, or Fivviai, which leads out of the Piazza dell' Annunziata past the Spedale degl' Innocenti.

places.name: Duomo, Piazza del (Real)
places.desc: Duomo, Piazza del (Real),The square in Florence around the Duomo, where several important events in Romola take place. The Piazza del Duomo takes its name from the Duomo or Cathedral which it surrounds.

places.name: Duomo, or, Santa Maria del Fiore (Real)
places.desc: Duomo, or, Santa Maria del Fiore (Real),The Cathedral of Florence; the church in which Savonarola preaches. When Baldassarre Calvo escapes from the French soldiers it is on the steps of the Duomo that he clutches Tito Melema, who thus becomes aware of his foster father's presence in Florence. Later, within the Duomo, Baldassarre hears Savonarola preach and is seen by Romola. The Duomo, or Cathedral of Santa Maria del Fiore (so called from the lily which figures on the arms of Florence) is the present Cathedral of Florence. It was begun in the last decade of the thirteenth century by Arnolfo di Cambio. Giotto, the architect from 1332-6, began the tower. The dome was added by Brunelleschi during the first half of the fifteenth century and the church was finally consecrated 1436. The present facade was erected 1875-87.

places.name: Delos (Real)
places.desc: Delos (Real),Place to which Baldassarre Calvo and Tito Melema had been journeying when they were attacked by pirates. A Greek island, one of the Cyclades, famous for its ancient ruins.

places.name: Dante's House (Real)
places.desc: Dante's House (Real),This house, which, rebuilt, is still standing in the Via Dante Alighieri, is said to have been the birthplace of Dante.

places.name: Corinth (Real)
places.desc: Corinth (Real),A city where Baldassarre Calvo is held in slavery; from which he sends to Tito Melema his appeal for aid. Corinth, an ancient city in Greece; in the Middle Ages it had belonged to Venice but at the time of Romola was in the possession of the Turks.

places.name: Cocomero, Via del (Real)
places.desc: Cocomero, Via del (Real),Street in Florench near San Marco, where Fra Domenico preaches Lenten sermons to the women in 1496. The street formerly called Via del Cocomero is now the Via Ricasoli, extending from the Piazza San Marco to the Piazza del Duomo.

places.name: Certaldo (Real)
places.desc: Certaldo (Real),A place on the Siena Road, where Tito Melema receives a message from Piero de' Medici. This is the small town of Certaldo on the Elsa, in Tuscany, 18 miles south-west of Florence.

places.name: Cerretani, Via De' (Real)
places.desc: Cerretani, Via De' (Real),Street in Florence along which Tito Melema and the French dignitary proceed to the Duomo when preparing for the French king's entry into Florence. The Via de' Cerretani, named after an old family, extends from the Piazza di San Giovanni toward the Piazza Santa Maria Novella, as far as the Via Panzani.

places.name: Casentino, The (Real)
places.desc: Casentino, The (Real),A region from which the country people come to the fairs in Florence. The Casentino is the district of the upper valley of the Arno.

places.name: Careggi (Real)
places.desc: Careggi (Real),The country house of the Medici near Florence, where Lorenzo de' Medici died. The Villa Medicea di Careggi bought by Cosimo the Elder and reconstructed for him after 1433. It was set on fire, but not destroyed, in 1529, and still retains practically its original form.

places.name: Canto di Paglia (Real)
places.desc: Canto di Paglia (Real),Place in Florence where Maestro Tacca, the doctor, lives. The Canto alla Paglia ("Straw Corner") at a corner of the Borgo S. Lorenzo and Via dei Cerretani took this name from the fact that until comparatively recent years the market for hay and straw was held there daily.

places.name: Calimara, The (Real)
places.desc: Calimara, The (Real),Street in Florence where Burchiello's barber shop was located. The Via Calimara (or Calimala), one of the most ancient of Florentine streets, leads from the site of the former Mercato Vecchio, now the modern Piazza Vittorio Emanuele, to the Via Porta Rossa. The residence and offices of the Guild of the Calimala (workers of foreign cloth) were in this street.

places.name: Borgo Santa Croce (Real)
places.desc: Borgo Santa Croce (Real),Street in Florence near which Tito Melema hears the sound of Niccolo Caparra's forge. The Borgo Santa Croce extends from the Church of Santa croce to the Via de' Benci.

places.name: Borgo Pinti (Real)
places.desc: Borgo Pinti (Real),Street in Flroence where Tito Melema meets Romola when she is hastening to see her dying brother. The Borgo Pinti is a long street running to the Porta Pinti (Piazzale Donatello).

places.name: Borgo la Croce (Real)
places.desc: Borgo la Croce (Real),Street in Florence where Romola finds the runaway Lillo. The Borgo la Croce extends from the Piazza San Ambrogio to the Piazza Beccaria (Porta alla Croce).

places.name: Borgo di San Lorenzo (Real)
places.desc: Borgo di San Lorenzo (Real),Street in Florence up which one of Baldassarre Calvo's fellow prisoners turns when he escapes. The Borgo San Lorenzo leads from near the Baptistery to the Piazza San Lorenzo.

places.name: Borgo Degli Albizzi (Real)
places.desc: Borgo Degli Albizzi (Real),Street in Florence where Monna Brigida lives. The Borgo degli Albizzi (now Albizi) is an old street of Florence, continuing the Via del Corso and extending to the Via Giuseppe Verdi. It was named after the Albizzi family, which had many houses there.

places.name: Borgo de' Greci (Real)
places.desc: Borgo de' Greci (Real),Street in Florence near which Romola and Tito meet a funeral Carnival procession while returning from their betrothal in Santa Croce. The Borgo de' Greci, a street leading from the Piazza di Santa Croce, has been said mistakenly to take its name from the fact that the Byzantine Emperor and his brother, the Greek Patriarch, were there in 1436. The name is, however, of earlier date, and may be derived from the Greci family.

places.name: Bologna (Real)
places.desc: Bologna (Real),Italian city; Romola plans to go there when she starts to leave her husband Tito Melema. Bologna, in the province of Bologna, in the old Romagna, north of Florence.

places.name: Bogoli, Hill of (Real)
places.desc: Bogoli, Hill of (Real),Hill back of the Via de' Bardi, from which stone was quarried. The Bogoli, now the Boboli Hill, was named after an old family, the Borgoli, that formerly held property there. The Boboli Garden is on the hill.

places.name: Benci, Via de' (Real)
places.desc: Benci, Via de' (Real),Street in Florence along which Tito Melema sometimes passes on his way to or from the Via de' Bardi. The Via de' Benci which leads from the Piazza Santa Croce towards the Ponte alle Grazie is named after the Benci family. At the time of Romola the part of the present Via de' Benci from the Borgo Santa Croce to the bridge which was called Via del Fosso.

places.name: Bari (Real)
places.desc: Bari (Real),Tito Melema's birthplace. An Italian seaport, on the Adriatic, in Apulia.

places.name: Bargello, The (Real)
places.desc: Bargello, The (Real),Public building in Florence; within its court Bernardo del Nero and the other Mediceans were executed. The Palazza del Podesta, on the Via del Proconsolo, commonly known as the Bargello, was from about 1261 the residence of the Podesta or chief magistrate of Florence ; from 1574 it was a prison and office of the chief of police. Now it is a National Museum.

places.name: Bardi, Via de' (Real)
places.desc:
Bardi, Via de' (Real),Street in Florence where Romola de' Bardi lived. The picturesque Via de' Bardi, one of the oldest
streets in Florence, extends from the Piazza de' Mozzi to the Via Guicciardini. Some parts of it were altered in the nineteenth century, in the making of the quay of Lung Arno Torrigiani.

places.name: Baptistery (Real)
places.desc: Baptistery (Real),The Battistero, or Church of San Giovanni Battista, probably founded in the seventh or eighth century and remodeled around 1200, which, until the twelfth century, was the cathedral of Florence. It still is the church in which all children born in Florence are baptized.

places.name: Badia, Church of the (Real)
places.desc: Badia, Church of the (Badia),Church in Florence, where Romola meets Baldasserre Calvo. The Church of La Badia, originally a Benedictine convent (abbatia) founded in the tenth century by Willa, mother of the Margrave Hugo; the present church was largely reconstructed in the seventeenth century.

places.name: Athens (Real)
places.desc: Athens (Real),Greek city which Baldasserre Calvo and Tito Melema visited to study Greek inscriptions. At the time of Romola Athens was in the possession of the Turks, who had captured it in 1458. For a long time after its capture it almost disappeared from the knowledge of the western world.

places.name: Ashby (Real)
places.desc: Ashby (Real),The town for which Hetty Sorrel starts when she leaves Stoniton to go to Windsor. Probably Ashby de la Zouch, a town about 164 miles south of Derby (Stoniton).

places.name: Arno (Real)
places.desc: Arno (Real),The river which flows through Florence, into which Tito Melema leaps when pursued by the mob.

places.name: Arkwright's Mills, Cromford (Real)
places.desc: Arkwright's Mills, Cromford (Real),The mills established at Cromford, Derbyshire, in 1771 by Sir Richard Arkwright, cotton spinning inventor.

places.name: Arezzo (Real)
places.desc: Arezzo (Real),Town, Baldasserre's pretended destination when he leaves the hospital. A town 54 miles southeast of Florence.

places.name: Antioch (Real)
places.desc: Antioch (Real),City where Baldasserre Calvo was held in slavery. The ancient capital of Syria.

places.name: Annunziata, Piazza dell' (Real)
places.desc: Annunziata, Piazza dell' (Real),Square in Florence, where the Fierucola (Peasant's Fair) is held. The Piazza dell' Annunziata is the square in front of the Church of the Annunziata, from which it takes its name.

places.name: Annunziata, Church of the (Real)
places.desc: Annunziata, Church of the (Real),Church in Florence, where Tito Melema finds Tessa on the day of the Fierucola. Church of the Santissima Annunziata on the north-east side of the Piazza dell' Annunziata, founded 1250.

places.name: Ancona (Real)
places.desc: Ancona (Real),Place near which Tito Melema had been shipwrecked. An Italian port on the Adriatic.

places.name: Albergo Dell' Italia (Real)
places.desc: Albergo Dell' Italia (Real),Hotel in Genoa where Daniel Deronda and his mother meet.

places.name: Ajaccio (Real)
places.desc: Ajaccio (Real),One of the Mediterranean towns where the Grandcourts touch on their yachting trip. The capital of Corsica, on the west coast of that island.

places.name: Adimari, Corso degli (Real)
places.desc: Adimari, Corso degli (Real),A street in Florence where Tito Melema is walking before he meets Tessa on the day of San Giovanni. The Corso degli Adimari, named from the houses of the Adimari family which occupied its whole length, was a short street extending south from the Piazzi del Duomo to the Via degli Speciali. It is now part of the Via Calzaioli.

places.name: Genoa (Real)
places.desc: Genoa (Real),City in Italy, where Daniel Deronda meets his mother, and where Mr. and Mrs. Grandcourt are staying when Grandcourt is drowned. In Romola, Baldassarre Calvo is taken to Genoa, when a Genoese merchant rescues him from slavery at Corinth, and in Genoa he sees the man who has bought Tito Melema's onyx ring.

places.name: Constantinople (Real)
places.desc: Constantinople (Real),In Felix Holt Harold Transome goes to Constantinople as an attache of the British Embassy; in Romola Constantinople is one of the places where Tito Melema had lived. Constantinople, the capital of the Eastern Empire, was captured by the Turks in 1453, and after that date many Greek scholars made their way from there to Italy.

places.name: Rome (Real)
places.desc: Rome (Real),In Middlemarch Rome is the city to which Mr. and Mrs. Casaubon go on their wedding journey. In Romola Tito Melema twice goes there on political errands, and it is the centre of the agitation against Savonarola, under the Pope's leadership. Under Alexander the Sixth (1492-1503), who was Pope during the period of Romola, the will of the Pope was absolute in Rome, and the Papal states of which he was the head were one of the five great powers of Italy.

places.name: Naples (Real)
places.desc: Naples (Real),The Naples which figures in Daniel Deronda and Felix Holt is the city of Naples; that in Romola is the Kingdom of Naples, which in the fifteenth century was one of the five great powers of Italy. At the beginning of Romola its ruler was the "Spanish-born old King Ferdinand", who was succeeded 1494 by his son Alfonso.

places.name: Mediterranean (Real)
places.desc: Mediterranean (Real),The Mediterranean is a definite part of the scene in two of the novels. In Daniel Deronda Gwendolen Harleth and her husband, Grandcourt, go yachting on the Mediteranean, and Grandcourt is drowned in it while sailing a small boat near Genoa, and Gwendolen is rescued from drowning when she leaps over board after him. In Romola, Romola de' Bardi, sick at heart after her god-father's execution, sets herself adrift in a small fishing boat, hoping that she may never return ; instead she is carried to the plague-stricken village, where, in helping the sufferers, she wins back some peace and strength for herself.

places.name: Milan (Real)
places.desc: Milan (Real),The Italian city where Lady Cheverel aids the poor musician Signor Sarti, and later rescues his orphan daughter, the little Caterina.

misc.name: Archery Meeting
misc.desc: A meeting of the Brackenshaw Archery Club, at which Grandcourt first sees Gwendolen Harleth.

misc.name: "Oedipus and Antigone at Colonos"
misc.desc: Subject of a picture which Piero di Cosimo paints for Giovanni Vespucci, using Romola and her father as models.

misc.name: "Hound of the Lord"
misc.desc: A Dominican; a play (Domini Canes) upon the name of the order. Name applied to Fra Girolamo.

misc.name: "At the Battle of Clavijo"
misc.desc: Song in Spanish Gypsy sung by Arias, the page.

misc.name: "Ar hyd y nos"
misc.desc: An air which Fred Vincy practices on his flute. "Ar hyd y nos" (All Through the Night), a Welsh air.

misc.name: "All Things Journey, Sun and Moon"
misc.desc: One of the songs of Juan, the minstrel.

misc.name: Impruneta, Madonna dell' (Real)
misc.desc: An image of the Virgin of extreme sanctity which is brought from the Church of l'Impruneta outside Florence and carried in solemn procession through the city to break the famine of 1496. "For a  century and a half there were records how the Florentinces, suffering from drought, or flood, or famine, or pestilence, or the threat of wars, had fetched the potent image within their walls, and had found deliverance. And grateful honour had been done to her and her ancient church of L'Impruneta. . . The Florentines were deeply convinced of her graciousness to them, so that the sight of her tabernacle within their walls was like the parting of the cloud, and the proverb ran, that the Florentines had a Madonna who would do what they pleased." A famous wonder-worker image which was found buried at Impruneta and was said to have uttered a cry when the workman's spade struck it. It was probably made by a Luca, of the eleventh century, though legend attributed it to St. Luke.

misc.name: Fierucola (Real)
misc.desc: The "Little Fair"; a fair or festival held by the peasants on the seventh of September, the eve of the Nativity of the Virgin, in the Piazza dell' Annunziata. Tito Melema, whose interest has been aroused by Nello's description of the Fierucola, goes to see the celebration, find Tessa in the Church of the Annunziata, wanders through the fair with her, and ends by going through a mock marriage ceremony which she ignorantly believes to be real. Guido Biage, in his edition of Romola, points out that it is not certainn that the Fierucola was celbrated as early as the time of Romola, as, according to one tradition, the festival commemorates the taking of Siena in 1555.
